questions.question: Which of the following are true about Go? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Go is an interpreted language like Python
Go has built-in support for concurrent programming
Go compiles to native machine code
Go requires a virtual machine to run

questions.explanation: Go was developed at Google, compiles directly to native machine code (no VM needed), and has built-in concurrency support through goroutines and channels. It's a compiled language, not interpreted.

questions.question: What does 'package main' indicate in a Go program?

options.text: The program will have a main() function
This package can be imported by other programs

questions.explanation: The 'package main' declaration indicates this is an executable program (not a library). Executable programs must have both 'package main' and a 'func main()' as the entry point.

questions.question: Arrange the steps to create and run a new Go project in the correct order:

items.text: Create a new directory for your project
Run 'go mod init' to initialize the module
Create a main.go file with your code

questions.explanation: First create a directory, then initialize a Go module with 'go mod init', create your source file, and finally run it with 'go run'.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'fmt' package in Go?
questions.explanation: The 'fmt' package (short for format) provides functions for formatted I/O - both printing output (like Println) and reading input (like Scanf).

questions.question: Which command compiles and immediately runs a Go program?
questions.explanation: 'go run' compiles your code to a temporary location and immediately executes it. 'go build' only compiles and creates an executable file without running it.
